subject: Re: [junit] Including test cases with production code
msgSnippet: ... I m specifically referring to products where the source code is part and parcel of the product or the product provides a Java API.  It s not always
messageBody:
Vladimir Bossicard wrote:

>>>Can someone explain why someone (i.e. a customer) would want to clutter
>>>their storage or bandwith with test cases?
>>>
>>In general, if the customer is able to modify the application source
>>code, then the test cases carry their weight. Examples include open
>>source applications or products where the source code is the primary
>>deliverable (e.g. frameworks).
>>
>
> I think that we are talking about two different products: the final application (a jar in the Java world) and the development environment.
> The tests code is part of the source code but not part of the final application.
> You always can keep the tests in the cvs tree or a separate package for download. If the customer has the knowledge to modify the code, he certainly know how to get code from a cvs tree :-)
>
> -Vladimir
>


I'm specifically referring to products where the source code is part and
parcel of the product or the product provides a Java API. It's not
always necessary to ship all of the test cases, but relevant test cases
that document and validate the use of the product should easily make up
for their storage and bandwidth penalties.

Mike
